description:
Story:

A host has a power fluctuation and reboots.

The VM state in the DB is Active.
The VM state in the driver is Shutoff.

The sysadmin goes in to xenserver and xe starts all the instances.

nova.compute.manager.Manager._run_image_cache_manager_pass runs,
  it finds that the DB vs driver states are incompatible,
  it says the driver is kind, and updates the DB

now all the VMs that sysadmin started are down again.

-----
Work around:

After host reboots, shut down the compute service, start the VMs, start the compute service

-----
Background:

There used to be an option: 'start_guests_on_host_boot'

The trouble with it was that it started VMs, even if the DB state was suspended.

It was removed here: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/16698/

------
Suggested fix:

Re-add a nova.conf option: 'start_guests_on_host_boot'

But make it submit to the DB state, and only start a guest if it is labeled as running in the DB.
title: start guests on host reboot

comments.content:
So the trouble seems to be with the xenapi only so far.

Order of events:

host starts
compute node starts
nova.service..calls init_host
  init_host starts powering up hosts
    nova.virt.xenapi..resume_state_on_host_boot
      virt.xenapi.vmops.power_on then _start
        xenapi.start_on      <== This is asynchronous
nova.service calls self.periodic_tasks, which eventualy calls compute.manager._sync_power_states

_sync_power_states finds that the instances haven't actually powered up yet and tells the DB that they are down and calls conductor.compute_stop .. which calls nova.compute.api..stop .. which shuts down the VM, even though its starting to power up.

comments.content:
Looking through commits from 4/16 to 4/20 I don't find anything was changed to address this issue.

I checked xenserver docs and it says api calls are by default synchronous i.e. VM.start won't return until the vm has started booting:

http://docs.vmd.citrix.com/XenServer/4.0.1/sdk/ch04.html#id2538437

During _sync_power_states, the power state of the vm is queried using VM.get_record and the issue you saw implies that after a vm has started booting, its power_state from VM.get_record isn't necessarily "Running." I'm not familiar with xenserver vm power state transitions, is this expected that once boot has started it's not necessarily "Running?"

The available states are:

http://docs.vmd.citrix.com/XenServer/4.1.0/1.0/en_gb/api/docs/html/API/Classes/VM/Fields/power_state.html
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/virt/xenapi/vm_utils.py#L134
